segment.source: Text block
segment.target: Text block

segment.source: Text block is the primary control for displaying read-only text in apps.
segment.target: Text block is the primary control for displaying read-only text in apps.

segment.source: You can use it to display single-line or multi-line text, inline hyperlinks, and text with formatting like bold, italic, or underlined.
segment.target: You can use it to display single-line or multi-line text, inline hyperlinks, and text with formatting like bold, italic, or underlined.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: TextBlock class
segment.target: TextBlock class

segment.source: Text property
segment.target: Text property

segment.source: Inlines property
segment.target: Inlines property

segment.source: Is this the right control?
segment.target: Is this the right control?

segment.source: A text block is typically easier to use and provides better text rendering performance than a rich text block, so it's preferred for most app UI text.
segment.target: A text block is typically easier to use and provides better text rendering performance than a rich text block, so it's preferred for most app UI text.

segment.source: You can easily access and use text from a text block in your app by getting the value of the Text property.
segment.target: You can easily access and use text from a text block in your app by getting the value of the Text property.

segment.source: It also provides many of the same formatting options for customizing how your text is rendered.
segment.target: It also provides many of the same formatting options for customizing how your text is rendered.

segment.source: Although you can put line breaks in the text, text block is designed to display a single paragraph and doesn’t support text indentation.
segment.target: Although you can put line breaks in the text, text block is designed to display a single paragraph and doesn’t support text indentation.

segment.source: Use a RichTextBlock when you need support for multiple paragraphs, multi-column text or other complex text layouts, or inline UI elements like images.
segment.target: Use a RichTextBlock when you need support for multiple paragraphs, multi-column text or other complex text layouts, or inline UI elements like images.

segment.source: For more info about choosing the right text control, see the Text controls article.
segment.target: For more info about choosing the right text control, see the Text controls article.

segment.source: Examples
segment.target: Examples

segment.source: Create a text block
segment.target: Create a text block

segment.source: Here's how to define a simple TextBlock control and set its Text property to a string.
segment.target: Here's how to define a simple TextBlock control and set its Text property to a string.

segment.source: Content model
segment.target: Content model

segment.source: There are two properties you can use to add content to a TextBlock: Text and Inlines.
segment.target: There are two properties you can use to add content to a TextBlock: Text and Inlines.

segment.source: The most common way to display text is to set the Text property to a string value, as shown in the previous example.
segment.target: The most common way to display text is to set the Text property to a string value, as shown in the previous example.

segment.source: You can also add content by placing inline flow content elements in the TextBox.Inlines property, like this.
segment.target: You can also add content by placing inline flow content elements in the TextBox.Inlines property, like this.

segment.source: Elements derived from the Inline class, such as Bold, Italic, Run, Span, and LineBreak, enable different formatting for different parts of the text.
segment.target: Elements derived from the Inline class, such as Bold, Italic, Run, Span, and LineBreak, enable different formatting for different parts of the text.

segment.source: For more info, see the Formatting text section.
segment.target: For more info, see the Formatting text section.

segment.source: The inline Hyperlink element lets you add a hyperlink to your text.
segment.target: The inline Hyperlink element lets you add a hyperlink to your text.

segment.source: However, using Inlines also disables fast path text rendering, which is discussed in the next section.
segment.target: However, using Inlines also disables fast path text rendering, which is discussed in the next section.

segment.source: Performance considerations
segment.target: Performance considerations

segment.source: Whenever possible, XAML uses a more efficient code path to layout text.
segment.target: Whenever possible, XAML uses a more efficient code path to layout text.

segment.source: This fast path both decreases overall memory use and greatly reduces the CPU time to do text measuring and arranging.
segment.target: This fast path both decreases overall memory use and greatly reduces the CPU time to do text measuring and arranging.

segment.source: This fast path applies only to TextBlock, so it should be preferred when possible over RichTextBlock.
segment.target: This fast path applies only to TextBlock, so it should be preferred when possible over RichTextBlock.

segment.source: Certain conditions require TextBlock to fall back to a more feature-rich and CPU intensive code path for text rendering.
segment.target: Certain conditions require TextBlock to fall back to a more feature-rich and CPU intensive code path for text rendering.

segment.source: To keep text rendering on the fast path, be sure to follow these guidelines when setting the properties listed here.
segment.target: To keep text rendering on the fast path, be sure to follow these guidelines when setting the properties listed here.

segment.source: Text: The most important condition is that the fast path is used only when you set text by explicitly setting the Text property, either in XAML or in code (as shown in the previous examples).
segment.target: Text: The most important condition is that the fast path is used only when you set text by explicitly setting the Text property, either in XAML or in code (as shown in the previous examples).

segment.source: Setting the text via TextBlock’s Inlines collection (such as ) will disable the fast path, due to the potential complexity of multiple formats.
segment.target: Setting the text via TextBlock’s Inlines collection (such as ) will disable the fast path, due to the potential complexity of multiple formats.

segment.source: CharacterSpacing: Only the default value of 0 is fast path.
segment.target: CharacterSpacing: Only the default value of 0 is fast path.

segment.source: Typography: Only the default values for the various Typography properties are fast path.
segment.target: Typography: Only the default values for the various Typography properties are fast path.

segment.source: TextTrimming: Only the None, CharacterEllipsis, and WordEllipsis values are fast path.
segment.target: TextTrimming: Only the None, CharacterEllipsis, and WordEllipsis values are fast path.

segment.source: The Clip value disables the fast path.
segment.target: The Clip value disables the fast path.

segment.source: LineStackingStrategy: If LineHeight is not 0, the BaselineToBaseline and MaxHeight values disable the fast path.
segment.target: LineStackingStrategy: If LineHeight is not 0, the BaselineToBaseline and MaxHeight values disable the fast path.

segment.source: IsTextSelectionEnabled: Only false is fast path.
segment.target: IsTextSelectionEnabled: Only false is fast path.

segment.source: Setting this property to true disables the fast path.
segment.target: Setting this property to true disables the fast path.

segment.source: You can set the DebugSettings.IsTextPerformanceVisualizationEnabled property to true during debugging to determine whether text is using fast path rendering.
segment.target: You can set the DebugSettings.IsTextPerformanceVisualizationEnabled property to true during debugging to determine whether text is using fast path rendering.

segment.source: When this property is set to true, the text that is on the fast path displays in a bright green color.
segment.target: When this property is set to true, the text that is on the fast path displays in a bright green color.

segment.source: TipThis feature is explained in depth in this session from Build 2015- XAML Performance: Techniques for Maximizing Universal Windows App Experiences Built with XAML.
segment.target: TipThis feature is explained in depth in this session from Build 2015- XAML Performance: Techniques for Maximizing Universal Windows App Experiences Built with XAML.

segment.source: You typically set debug settings in the OnLaunched method override in the code-behind page for App.xaml, like this.
segment.target: You typically set debug settings in the OnLaunched method override in the code-behind page for App.xaml, like this.

segment.source: In this example, the first TextBlock is rendered using the fast path, while the second is not.
segment.target: In this example, the first TextBlock is rendered using the fast path, while the second is not.

segment.source: When you run this XAML in debug mode with IsTextPerformanceVisualizationEnabled set to true, the result looks like this.
segment.target: When you run this XAML in debug mode with IsTextPerformanceVisualizationEnabled set to true, the result looks like this.

segment.source: Text rendered in debug mode
segment.target: Text rendered in debug mode

segment.source: CautionThe color of text that is not on the fast path is not changed.
segment.target: CautionThe color of text that is not on the fast path is not changed.

segment.source: If you have text in your app with its color specified as bright green, it is still displayed in bright green when it's on the slower rendering path.
segment.target: If you have text in your app with its color specified as bright green, it is still displayed in bright green when it's on the slower rendering path.

segment.source: Be careful to not confuse text that is set to green in the app with text that is on the fast path and green because of the debug settings.
segment.target: Be careful to not confuse text that is set to green in the app with text that is on the fast path and green because of the debug settings.

segment.source: Formatting text
segment.target: Formatting text

segment.source: Although the Text property stores plain text, you can apply various formatting options to the TextBlock control to customize how the text is rendered in your app.
segment.target: Although the Text property stores plain text, you can apply various formatting options to the TextBlock control to customize how the text is rendered in your app.

segment.source: You can set standard control properties like FontFamily, FontSize, FontStyle, Foreground, and CharacterSpacing to change the look of the text.
segment.target: You can set standard control properties like FontFamily, FontSize, FontStyle, Foreground, and CharacterSpacing to change the look of the text.

segment.source: You can also use inline text elements and Typography attached properties to format your text.
segment.target: You can also use inline text elements and Typography attached properties to format your text.

segment.source: These options affect only how the TextBlock displays the text locally, so if you copy and paste the text into a rich text control, for example, no formatting is applied.
segment.target: These options affect only how the TextBlock displays the text locally, so if you copy and paste the text into a rich text control, for example, no formatting is applied.

segment.source: NoteRemember, as noted in the previous section, inline text elements and non-default typography values are not rendered on the fast path.
segment.target: NoteRemember, as noted in the previous section, inline text elements and non-default typography values are not rendered on the fast path.

segment.source: Inline elements
segment.target: Inline elements

segment.source: The Windows.UI.Xaml.Documents namespace provides a variety of inline text elements that you can use to format your text, such as Bold, Italic, Run, Span, and LineBreak.
segment.target: The Windows.UI.Xaml.Documents namespace provides a variety of inline text elements that you can use to format your text, such as Bold, Italic, Run, Span, and LineBreak.

segment.source: You can display a series of strings in a TextBlock, where each string has different formatting.
segment.target: You can display a series of strings in a TextBlock, where each string has different formatting.

segment.source: You can do this by using a Run element to display each string with its formatting and by separating each Run element with a LineBreak element.
segment.target: You can do this by using a Run element to display each string with its formatting and by separating each Run element with a LineBreak element.

segment.source: Here's how to define several differently formatted text strings in a TextBlock by using Run objects separated with a LineBreak.
segment.target: Here's how to define several differently formatted text strings in a TextBlock by using Run objects separated with a LineBreak.

segment.source: Here's the result.
segment.target: Here's the result.

segment.target: Text formatted with run elements

segment.source: Typography
segment.target: Typography

segment.source: The attached properties of the Typography class provide access to a set of Microsoft OpenType typography properties.
segment.target: The attached properties of the Typography class provide access to a set of Microsoft OpenType typography properties.

segment.source: You can set these attached properties either on the TextBlock, or on individual inline text elements.
segment.target: You can set these attached properties either on the TextBlock, or on individual inline text elements.

segment.source: These examples show both.
segment.target: These examples show both.
